info.name: Functional Testing v2.0
info.description:
This functional test suite validates the core behavior of the API endpoints to ensure they meet specified business requirements and operate reliably under expected conditions. It focuses on verifying the correctness of API responses for valid and invalid inputs across common use cases.

### Scope of Tests

The suite covers the following test categories:

- **Response Status Codes**
    
    Verifies that the correct HTTP status codes (e.g., 200, 400, 401, 404, 500) are returned according to the request context.
    
- **Payload Validation**
    
    Ensures the structure and data types of the response payload match the expected schema using assertions (e.g., `pm.expect()` for property presence and types).
    
- **Business Logic Verification**
    
    Tests functional rules such as pagination, item limits, filtering mechanisms, and mandatory field enforcement.
    
- **Error Handling**
    
    Confirms that meaningful error responses, including proper codes and descriptive messages, are returned for invalid requests or missing data.
    
- **Boundary Condition Testing**
    
    Validates system behavior under edge conditions like empty responses or maximum input limits.
    

This suite is intended for CI/CD integration and supports environment-specific testing (e.g., development, staging) via Postman environments and variable configurations. Each test case is stateless and idempotent, ensuring consistent results across repeated executions.

## Setup Instructions

### Collection Configuration

- **Collection Variables**
    
    Store common configuration values‚Äîsuch as base URLs and auth tokens‚Äîat the collection level to enable reuse and centralized management.
    
- **Environment Requirements**
    
    A Postman environment must be selected before execution. This environment supplies dynamic values like environment-specific URLs and credentials.
    
- **Collection-Level Pre-request Scripts**
    
    Define global setup logic (e.g., timestamp generation, authentication headers) that executes before each request for consistent initialization.
    
- **Folder-Level Pre-request Scripts**
    
    Use folder-scoped scripts for modular setup logic such as test data creation, parameter configuration, or group-specific headers.
    
- **Automated Functional Assertions**
    
    Each request includes tests to validate HTTP status codes, response payload structure, and headers.
    

**Note:** Ensure a valid environment is selected and all necessary variables are properly configured prior to running the test suite.

## Database

We are using the [Sommer Demo DB](https://jtlgmbh-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/thomas_hoffmann_jtl-software_com/EU9qR4VW0YBDqRfcTQgkv_sBlr5Q0OZp7SMxhVkYOiZaVw?e=RFqxqn) (around 300 MB) for the functional tests.

Ensure that you have installed the database and register the app in this DB.

Use the app registration data (app-sersion, app-id, api-key) to build your own environment.

## Creating a New Environment

Create a new Postman environment with the following key-value pairs:

| Key | Description |
| --- | --- |
| `tenantName` | Your database name (e.g., `eazybusiness, mandant_1, ...`) |
| `apiKey` | The API key from your app registration |
| `appID` | The App ID from your app registration |
| `appVersion` | The version of your registered app |
| `runAsUser` | User ID to execute as (default: `1`) |
| `baseURL` | Base URL of your REST API instance (default: `http://localhost:5883`) |
| `authorizationValue` | Use the format `Wawi {{apiKey}}` (no backticks) |
| `expectedMaxAmountOfCustomers` | The expected number of customers in your database |
| `expectedMaxAmountOfArticles` | The expected number of articles in your database |

üí° **Hint:** You can duplicate an existing environment and update the values as needed. Don‚Äôt forget to rename the copied environment to avoid confusion.

## Script Details

### Pre-request Script

This script sets required headers for each request, such as:

- `x-apiVersion`
    
- `x-AppId`
    
- _(and other custom headers)_
    

It also checks if all required variables (environment, collection) are setup-ed.

### Test (Post-request) Script

The post-request script provides reusable helper functions to:

- Validate the success response schema
    
- Check for expected status codes (success and error)
    
- Inspect the structure of error responses
    
- Utility methods, such as:
    
    - Extracting query parameters
        

üßæ To explore these functions, click the `Scripts` tab in Postman and review the inline documentation provided.

## Contribute

Follow the instruction of the [how to contribute](https://confluence.jtl-software.de/spaces/~THoffmann/pages/273687352/How+to+contribute) documentation.

pm.test("[XRAY:QWAWI-1142] Body is valid JSON and is an array", function () {
pm.expect.fail("Response body is not valid JSON");
"Response root must be a JSON array"
pm.test("[XRAY:QWAWI-1142] Response has at least one country", function () {
"Response array must contain at least one country item"
pm.test("[XRAY:QWAWI-1142] Each CountryItem contains all required fields with correct ISO formats", function () {
pm.expect(country, `${id}: Item must be an object`).to.be.an("object");
pm.expect(country.CountryIso, `${id}: CountryIso must be a string`).to.be.a("string");
pm.expect(country.CountryIso.length, `${id}: CountryIso must have exactly 2 characters`).to.eql(2);
pm.expect(country.CountryIso3, `${id}: CountryIso3 must be a string`).to.be.a("string");
pm.expect(country.CountryIso3.length, `${id}: CountryIso3 must have exactly 3 characters`).to.eql(3);
pm.expect(country.Name, `${id}: Name must be a non-empty string`).to.be.a("string").and.not.empty;
pm.expect(country.NumericIso, `${id}: NumericIso must be a number`).to.be.a("number");
`${id}: NumericIso for special ISO entries must be >= 0`
`${id}: NumericIso must be between 1 and 999 (ISO 3166-1 numeric)`
pm.expect(country.KnownStates, `${id}: KnownStates must be an array`).to.be.an("array");

pm.expect(country.Continent, `${id}: Continent must be a string`)
pm.expect(country.CurrencyIso, `${id}: CurrencyIso must be a string`).to.be.a("string");
pm.expect(country.CurrencyIso.length, `${id}: CurrencyIso must have exactly 3 characters`).to.eql(3);
pm.expect(country.DefaultCulture, `${id}: DefaultCulture must be a string`).to.be.a("string");
`${id}: DefaultCulture must be a valid BCP-47-like tag`
`${id}: DisplayNameState must be a non-empty string`
